message: Yesterday, I voted against a proposal that would have made unilateral adjustments to the Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE), an independent body that is designed to be a watchdog over Members of Congress.  While there should be important reforms made to the OCE that both Republicans and Democrats agree on, such as ensuring due process, I opposed this proposal because I believe it's important that these kinds of changes to the ethics office be made in a bipartisan effort and after robust debate and discussion from both parties. In addition, the American People have spoken overwhelmingly in the last election in sending us here to fix the real problems facing our Nation. This is not their priority.

I am humbled to begin my second term in office serving on behalf of the hardworking families, small businesses and communities of Maine’s 2nd District. There is so much work to be done for our State and for our Nation, and I’m ready to get right back to it.  In the next two years, I look forward to working closely with my Republican and Democratic colleagues in the House and Senate, with the White House, and with the members of the new administration to solve some of the biggest challenges facing our Nation, like protecting and growing jobs, ensuring our Veterans are provided the services they were promised, and securing our seniors’ hard-earned Medicare and Social Security benefits.

In the Obama Administration’s remaining days in office, they have hastily jammed through as many last-minute regulations as possible, without any approval from Congress or the American People. This evening, the House passed the Midnight Rules Relief Act, a bill that will help protect our small businesses and other job creators in Maine from these disastrous eleventh-hour rules. It’s past time we remove the power from bureaucrats and restore it to local communities and elected officials.

I was honored to join in reading our #Constitution on the House Floor today.  As a Member of Congress, one of my most solemn obligations is to support and defend our Constitution, the cornerstone and safeguard of our republic.

#BathBuiltBestBuilt  The men and women of Bath Iron Works are the best shipbuilders in the world, whose hard work keeps our Nation’s fleets strong across the globe. It was a great privilege to attend the christening of the USS Rafael Peralta in October 2015, named in honor of the late Marine Corps sergeant who was killed in action in Iraq. This awesome ship will carry his spirit forever.

Our Nation stands strong with our ally, Israel.  Tonight, a bipartisan and overwhelming majority in the House passed a measure condemning the UN’s anti-Israel resolution that they pushed through in December. While the UN undermined Israel, the Obama Administration refused to veto the action, abandoning one of our closest allies. This was unacceptable.  I will always stand with the people of Israel, our close ally, and will help work toward peace in the region.

Members of Congress and other public servants should be held to the highest standard. The American People sent us to Washington to work for them, not the other way around.  That's why I became a cosponsor of the TRUST Act. This bill will strip all taxpayer-funded portions of pensions for Members of Congress who are convicted of a felony, something that is just common sense.  From day one in office, I chose not to accept the congressional health care benefits and Thrift Savings that cost our taxpayers. Members of Congress exist to serve the people, and they should never betray that trust.

Every single day, we should stand up and show support for our police officers in Maine and across our nation. Today, on #NationalLawEnforcementAppreciationDay, we recognize their sacrifice and applaud their commitment to serving and protecting our families and communities.  Thank you to the thousands of officers in Maine for your great work on behalf of our citizens. I will always have your back.

Tonight, I am putting a blue light in my office window in Washington to recognize #NationalLawEnforcementAppreciationDay and to honor all of the officers across our Nation that protect our communities every day.  It is hard knowing that right now a massive manhunt is taking place in Orlando for the shooter of an officer who died earlier today. My thoughts and prayers go out to the family of the fallen officer, Sergeant Debra Clayton, and for the law enforcement who are—at this very minute—searching for the suspect. We are all praying for his quick arrest and for everyone to stay safe.

Tonight, the House acted to help protect internet broadband access for families and communities in underserved areas. The Small Business Broadband Deployment Act, which passed with unanimous and bipartisan support this evening, will provide relief for small internet service providers from unnecessary and burdensome procedures from federal regulators.

Tens of thousands of Mainers right now are suffocating under the spiking ObamaCare monthly premiums, co-pays, and deductibles while other health insurance options continue to shrink—and it’s getting worse. The Affordable Care Act is unaffordable. We must address this crisis.  This week, the House is taking the first step in repealing ObamaCare and replacing it with a plan that will eliminate job-killing taxes and regulations, such as the medical device tax, while retaining sensible provisions like coverage for pre-existing health conditions and keeping those 26-years-old or younger on their parents’ plans.  The American People put us in Congress to provide them with relief from this rapidly failing ObamaCare law. That is exactly what we are going to do.

This past week, I was tremendously proud and excited to join the House Veterans Affairs Committee, the body in Congress charged with improving care and services for our Veterans.  I am looking forward to serving as an instrumental force on behalf of our more than 60,000 Veterans in Maine’s 2nd District. Maine Veterans now have a direct seat at the table in Congress on some of the biggest issues facing them and their services at the VA. I am thrilled to continue to work on their behalf and to now use my direct role on this committee to hold the VA accountable and to make sure our Nation fulfills our promises to them.

Today, I was thrilled to stop by Saint Joseph's College of Maine to commemorate the school being awarded a $1.5 million grant from the Harold Alfond Foundation that will provide strong support for their nursing program.  I have enormous respect for the incredible work of our nurses in Maine and across our Nation. My mother served as a nurse in Central Maine for decades and I grew up watching her selfless devotion to the care of her patients. I am incredibly proud this grant will go to serve countless more dedicated individuals like my mom to pursue their careers in this noble and essential profession.  Saint Joe’s holds a special place in my heart after my years of coaching the Monks on the baseball diamond. I am thrilled this important support is going to an institution so worthy and eager to make a difference for all.

What an incredible pleasure it was to host the Madawaska High School band in my Washington, D.C. office this afternoon, as they get ready to perform in our nation’s capital and in the official Inauguration Parade during this week’s festivities. I’m so proud of your hard work and talents that got you here—after a two-day, 850 mile trip! Well done!

My office is excited to provide more than 150 tickets for tomorrow’s Inauguration Ceremony to 2nd District Mainers who made the trip to D.C. — from Eastport to Bethel. If you’re in town for the ceremony, please visit us at 1208 Longworth House Office Building today for some ice-cold Moxie! Give us a call at 202-225-6306 if you need any help with directions.

Today we witnessed the uniquely American tradition of a peaceful transfer of power that is orchestrated through the will of the American People by a democratic process that defines our great Nation. We are truly a shining city on a hill and a lasting example for the world. Now let's get back to work.

From DC to Maine, say it loud: Let's go Patriots!  The Madawaska High School band did a spectacular job representing our State this week in the Inauguration Parade. Hats off to everyone for a job well done!

Today, I applaud the President’s swift action in officially withdrawing the U.S. from the TPP, something that many Mainers agree with. As I have said time and time again, this massive and secretive trade deal is bad for Maine workers.  This is not a Democratic issue or a Republican issue. This is about jobs. This is about Maine jobs. I will continue to push for fair trade for Maine.

During #NationalSchoolChoiceWeek, it’s important to recognize how critical education is for our kids and families. My father was a public school teacher and a coach for decades in Central Maine. I understand firsthand that education choices help our children find their passions.  In Congress, I will continue to fight so that our parents, local school boards, and teachers decide how to run our classrooms—not bureaucrats in Washington.

I’m honored to join the Subcommittee on Terrorism and Illicit Finance, a congressional body charged with investigating and rooting out terrorism financing around the world. Our Nation faces grave threats from terror cells worldwide, which rely on the black market to finance their operations. In my new role, I’ll continue my work to thwart these terror groups and help keep America safe.

For generations, Maine families have been harvesting and working the flats of the intertidal zone here in Acadia National Park, and it is critical that their right to use the flats—providing for their livelihoods and businesses—is protected. I’m pleased to push forward a comprehensive solution to these harvesting issues and to provide much needed revisions to the boundary policies at Acadia to help the park, its surrounding communities and all those who come here to enjoy its beauty.

Today, I joined my first meeting as a new member on the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee. One of my top priorities in Congress is to use the full weight of my office to help our Veterans. I’m enormously proud to be a part of this body in Congress and look forward to continuing my work on behalf of the tens of thousands of Veterans in Maine’s 2nd District. I am thrilled to begin this new role and to give our heroes in Maine a direct voice on this important committee.

This week, as a member of the Congressional Rural Broadband Caucus, I joined a bipartisan group of lawmakers in the House and Senate in requesting President Trump to include the development of our Nation’s broadband networks as part of his infrastructure plan. Thousands of Mainers, especially those in our rural communities, are burdened with limited or no Internet access. As more and more essential business is done over the Internet, it’s critical we work to make sure our families throughout our State have access to reliable broadband.

Iran’s latest ballistic missile test is yet another egregious violation of UN resolutions and only more clearly proves they are continuing forward on a path to harm Americans and destroy our ally Israel. I fully support this swift action in issuing these new sanctions, firmly condemning Iran’s aggression, and holding them accountable.  Iran is the world’s leading state sponsor of terrorism and they cannot be trusted.
Getting the DC office geared up for Sunday. Let’s go Pats!

In 2015, after our Patriots were victorious in Super Bowl XLIX, I spoke on the House Floor to congratulate them on their well-earned, hard-fought win. Tonight, we witnessed the greatest comeback and Super Bowl victory of our lifetimes. Once again, our Patriots are world champions. Congrats Patriots Nation!!!

Government should exist to help—not hurt—our businesses and communities in Maine. All of the pieces are in place to grow jobs and businesses in Old Town on unused land at the town’s airport. But thanks to outdated restrictions, businesses are being denied the ability to develop there, despite support from town officials, community leaders and officials at the airport.  Today, after working closely with the town and community, I am proud to push forward this legislation to remove these outdated restrictions and enable Old Town to move ahead in attracting new businesses to the region, bringing new jobs to the area.

Congratulations to Lizzie Dunn of Houlton High School, the winner of this year’s Congressional Art Competition. I’m so delighted to display her artwork, “Jill,” in the halls of the U.S. Capitol where thousands of Americans from across the country can enjoy this piece of Maine’s culture and talent.  Every year, I am awestruck by the incredible talent and hard work of our high school students in Maine through this competition. I’m extraordinarily proud of all our participants this year!

Here’s to the greatest Super Bowl comeback and victory of all time!  On Sunday, our Patriots showed the world what can be achieved if you work hard and you never give up. Congress can certainly learn a thing or two from the world champs! I’m very proud of our Pats.

Maine’s forest economy continues to be a solid and vibrant pillar of our State. I am poised to continue to do everything I can to help strengthen our forest economy and to create and protect good-paying jobs for our families and communities across Maine.

I’m humbled for this recognition for my legislation, the Fair Treatment for Our National Guard and Reservists Act, that would allow our National Guard members to receive the same travel expense reimbursements as all other federal employees do.  I was honored Command Sergeant Major Steve Curtis of Millinocket was able to make the trip to Washington to join me! Steve originally brought this issue to my attention and has been an enormous help in putting the legislation together.

This evening, the House passed the HIRE Vets Act, a bill that will help encourage private businesses to hire and retain our Veterans who served our Nation honorably. As a proud cosponsor of this legislation and a member of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I’m pleased the House acted tonight to put our Veterans first, as they always should. I’m focused on making sure our heroes are given the support they were promised, have earned and deserve.

I’m enormously proud to become a co-chair of the House Paper and Packaging Caucus in the 115th Congress. In this new role, I’ll continue to be a strong voice in Congress on behalf of Maine’s resilient and robust paper and forest products industry, while also working to highlight the importance of the industry nationwide. This is all about jobs.

Our Nation has always stood strong with our close ally Israel and has shared with them the same vision for a peaceful and stable Middle East. I welcome Prime Minister Netanyahu on his visit today as our nations continue our support for one another. We stand with one of our most trusted allies.

Terrific news for Auburn Manufacturing, its workers, and our Great State of Maine!  Today, the ITC ruled—unanimously—that Chinese manufacturers have been conducting illegal trade that has harmed this Auburn-based textile manufacturer and threatened jobs there. I’m proud to have stood strong with Auburn Manufacturing and the rest of the Maine Delegation against this unfair trade and to celebrate this win for Maine jobs after a long, hard-fought battle.

Yesterday, I voted to strike down a misguided and hastily created rule from the Obama Administration that prohibits states, like Maine, from managing their own welfare programs.  In Maine, I’ve met and talked with community leaders, law enforcement members and several families across our District and have heard from them about some of the serious problems in our State’s welfare system. It’s important that different states, each with their own unique challenges and conditions, have the ability to implement their own policies regarding their welfare programs.

Today, I met with the Friends of Acadia—including the Acadia National Park Superintendent Kevin Schneider—in my Washington, D.C. office to discuss several different topics regarding the Park and the surrounding areas in Hancock County.  Among a number of different items, we talked about the bill that I recently reintroduced to help protect our traditional uses of the flats in and around Acadia, which provide for hundreds of jobs in the surrounding communities. I’m fighting every day to be a voice for Mainers in Washington. I’m fighting for Maine and for Maine jobs.

Great news for Maine jobs! I’m tremendously pleased to see more and more investment in Maine workers and in our communities.  In Congress, I will continue to work on behalf of our Maine families to help our State’s businesses grow and create more jobs, in every industry.

"I hope I shall possess firmness and virtue enough to maintain what I consider the most enviable of all titles, the character of an honest man" -President George Washington  On Presidents' Day, let's honor all who served our Nation in our highest office, starting with our first commander-in-chief, George Washington.

I’m tremendously proud to be at Colby College today—right around the corner from where I grew up—to celebrate the launch of a brand new program in Maine designed to encourage the best and brightest STEM college students to make our State their home after they graduate. This new program, sponsored by the Alfond Foundation, will provide college debt relief for STEM students who choose to use their skills working for a Maine-based company that is striving to create 200 jobs at its downtown Waterville location.  I am incredibly excited about this announcement and the continued efforts to revitalize Central Maine.

I was very pleased to return to Eastern Maine Medical Center in Bangor to tour the hospital’s state-of-the-art facilities and meet with patients and the dedicated personnel there. EMMC is an essential resource for our communities. I am always impressed with the devotion these nurses, physicians and administrators have for their work and for our Maine families. Thank you for having me stop by!

At this week’s Veterans’ Affairs Committee hearing, I questioned top officials from the Government Accountability Office and the Inspector General’s office about the serious problems at the VA regarding the mishandling of opioids and prescription drugs.  The fact of the matter is that the VA is doing a horrible job overseeing how drugs are being distributed to Veterans. This needs to be made right. We have a lot of Veterans who are in pain, and we have a lot of folks that are having problems with opioids and heroin—including those in the 2nd District of Maine—that I am very concerned about. Today, I welcomed a group of Maine Veterans of the Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW), including Peter Miesburger, to the U.S. Capitol for the House and Senate Veterans’ Affairs Committees’ joint hearing.  We don’t have our freedom and we don’t have our country without our Veterans. We cannot expect our young men and women to serve and put on a uniform if we cannot keep our promises and take care of those who have already served. I’m committed to making sure we keep these promises for our Vets and I will continue to fight for them—every day.

ICYMI: On Friday, I called on the Maine State Legislature and the Governor to act swiftly to make certain Maine is in compliance with the REAL ID law so Maine families and citizens are not adversely affected.  This is a dire situation. Maine-issued driver’s licenses are increasingly no longer acceptable forms of identification to access federal buildings and facilities. Maine businesses are suffering because their employees can’t access federal job sites. First responders, including our Maine firefighters, are not able to attend training at federal facilities. Our Veterans cannot access healthcare facilities located on military bases.  We need to act on this now.

ObamaCare is failing, and Congress must act to fix it. If we do nothing, Mainers who signed up for their ObamaCare plans in good faith will be left out in the cold even as they experience massive premium increases.  This new plan will bring much needed health insurance relief to the American People while keeping the promises made to them. It retains coverage for those with pre-existing health conditions; makes sure insurance companies sell health insurance to everyone who wants it; and offers to keep young adults on their parents' policies until age 26.‎  This legislation will bring Maine's positive experience with health insurance reform to the national stage. It will remove impediments in the ObamaCare law that prevent insurance companies from offering an array of plans at different prices. We want the young and the old, those in good health and those facing health challenges all to be able to afford the health insurance plans that fit their needs. Our goal is to make sure everyone has access to health care when they need it.  I will continue to work hard with Republicans and Democrats to make sure we achieve this.

Today, the House passed the Department of Defense (DOD) appropriations bill, the critical legislation that funds our Nation’s military.  This bill includes important support for the thousands of shipbuilders at Bath Iron Works, the best in the world. BIW plays an indispensable role in America’s defense and security around the globe. I’ll continue to do everything I can to provide them support to do their jobs and keep our Nation safe. #BathBuiltBestBuilt

Today, my bipartisan small business legislation passed out of the Financial Services Committee in a unanimous 58-0 vote. This bill, the Small Business Capital Formation Enhancement Act, will help local, small businesses in Maine to get the support they need to expand, succeed, and create more jobs.  Small businesses are the lifeblood of our economy in Maine, and it’s critical they get the tools they need to grow. I’m working with everyone and anyone—Democrats and Republicans—to help bring jobs to Maine.

Logging is one of the staple industries in Maine, largely consisting of family-run businesses that have operated for generations in our State. While major advances have been made in the trade in recent years that have drastically improved worker safety, outdated regulations from Washington haven’t kept up, preventing young Mainers from pursuing careers in timber harvesting.  I’m proud to push forward this important legislation to give young Mainers the opportunities to pursue a career path in logging, while also helping to maintain jobs in the industry in Maine for many more generations to come.

I’m honored to represent our 2nd District in Congress where I’m continuing to fight hard, every single day, to bring more jobs, opportunity and growth to our State and to make our home a better place.

I’m honored to now display the official Seal of the U.S. Navy in my Washington office. Thank you to all our Navy Veterans and active members from Maine for your service to our country.  If you’re ever down here in DC, please be sure to stop by the office so we can thank you personally!

This week, I voted to pass numerous Veterans bills to help ease administrative burdens and cut red tape at the VA. Our Veterans fought for us, and it’s time they’re taken care of.  I am incredibly proud to serve on the House Veterans Affairs Committee and to represent the more than 66,000 Veterans in our 2nd District. Every single day I am fighting to make sure you are given the care you were promised, have earned and deserve.

I’m extremely encouraged the President has signaled he shares in my mission to do everything we can to take care of our Veterans. This proposal promises vital increases to Veterans’ services in Maine and across the Nation, and I applaud those efforts.  However, I want to continue support for programs and agencies that serve our Maine families and communities—such as LIHEAP—and help protect our environment. ICYMI: Last week, I voted for three bills to help our Veterans get the care they need, clean up problems at the VA, and make sure our heroes’ constitutional rights are upheld. We must always continue to work hard for those who fought for our freedom.

Today, I went to the White House to meet directly with President Trump and to urge him and House Leadership to make important improvements in the ObamaCare replacement legislation. Specifically, I am pushing for increased benefits for those nearing retirement — those between the ages 50 and 64 — and families living in rural areas to be included in this health care proposal.  We also learned today that a number of new, key amendments will be made to the bill including giving states the flexibility to require non-disabled people without children to work, participate in training programs, or volunteer in order to receive taxpayer-funded Medicaid welfare benefits. Maine’s welfare reforms are working and the State, and other states, should have the option to continue these reforms.  We must make coverage more affordable and stop the individual market from imploding. Right now, ObamaCare is failing and Congress must act. I’ll continue to carefully study and push for changes in this health care relief proposal.

Our hardworking and dedicated Members and Reservists of the National Guard sacrifice incredibly to serve our country, often making extraordinary changes in their lives to travel long distances—sometimes hundreds of miles and even across state lines—for training. Unacceptably, most of the time our servicemembers are required to pay for their travel themselves.  We can’t expect these men and women to give up their time with family, but not provide them with the same tax treatment offered to other federal employees for their commutes. I’m proud to introduce this bicameral legislation to give our National Guard Members the support they surely deserve.

ObamaCare is failing, and it’s critical that Congress works to fix it to rescue the Maine families it’s impacting. But let’s do this right.  I agree that all legislation, especially a proposal for such an important policy change, must have enough time to be thoroughly reviewed by the American people and all lawmakers of all political parties. As I said, I have pushed to ensure those nearing retirement and in rural areas receive support in any proposed legislation.  In Congress, I will continue to push hard to find important solutions to the dire health care problems and challenges for Mainers. ObamaCare is failing and Congress must all work together to fix it.

ICYMI: Last week, I spoke at a Joint Veterans’ Affairs Committee hearing about the most important needs and challenges for our Veterans living in rural areas.  Maine has the highest percentage of rural Veterans in the Nation. Living in rural communities presents a number of unique challenges for our heroes when they need care. I’ve worked, and will continue to work, to make sure there are programs in place to ensure our Maine servicemebers have accessible and high quality care when they need it after returning home.

I am very pleased House Veterans’ Committee Chairman Phil Roe has called for a hearing to investigate recurring issues with the Department of Veterans’ Affairs Crisis Line (VCL).   Sadly, one of the most at-risk groups of Americans to suicide is our Veterans. While the VCL exists to help prevent these tragedies, many calls go unanswered. These flaws with the VCL are unacceptable; if we fail one of our Veterans, we have failed in our duty to all of them. We must do everything we can to give our Veterans the support and care they have earned.   I very much look forward to participating in the Veterans Affairs Committee’s efforts in fixing the VCL’s serious problems.

Certainly, I absolutely want to ensure there are proper safeguards in place to keep Mainers’ private data secure when they use the Internet, which is why I voted to remove this FCC rule.  The reality is this FCC rule creates a misleading sense of security for users. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is the regulatory body that has for years worked in this field to protect consumers’ data. The FCC can only monitor a segment of the Internet, leaving out huge swaths of the web they would not be able to administer. Creating rules enforced by the FCC would apply regulations to only a specific segment of the industry, while giving an unequal advantage and preference to a handful of companies who wouldn’t be under their jurisdiction. This is not the right way to regulate, as it would also undermine the very goal of protecting users’ data.  The Internet should remain a level playing field where consumers are protected consistently across the web, while preventing gaps in consumer protection from being created by any new privacy rules.

Maine’s forest products industry is a crucial pillar of our State’s economy and a unique part of our history and heritage.  Today, as a proud member of the Congressional Working Forests Caucus, I’m joining Republicans and Democrats in urging President Trump to push forward policies that will allow our critical working forests to remain a dependable resource for our local businesses and job creators. I’m pleased to send this letter to the President’s desk urging him to work with Congress in ensuring that our forest economy in Maine remains vibrant and sustainable for generations to come.

For the past century, Disabled American Veterans has lent critical support and care for our Veterans in Maine and across the Nation. To honor its 100 years of providing for our Veterans, I am asking my colleagues across the aisle and in both chambers of Congress to join in calling for the organization to be recognized with the distinction of an official commemorative stamp.  Thank you to DAV for standing up for our heroes for the past century and for many more years to come.

WARNING FOR OUR VETS: My office has received reports that scammers are attempting to take advantage of Veterans who use the Veterans Choice Program (VCP). An unknown group has set up a fraudulent VCP phone line to mislead Veterans using the service.  The correct VCP phone line is: 1-866-606-8198. The fraudulent phone line is: 1-800-606-8198.  Veterans can tell if they have reached the false phone line if:    -The speaker offers a $100 rebate in exchange for credit card information, or    -The speaker does not state that the caller has reached the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs of the VCP phone line.

In the last 48 hours my father suffered a stroke and I had to rush back home from Washington to help him. My own son has an asthma condition—a pre-existing condition. I've seen health care up close. We need to do the best job we possibly can when it comes to health care so Maine people get the care they need.   I have studied this health care issue carefully with one thing in mind: the People of Maine. I do not work for the Democrats, Republicans, or Washington bosses—I work only for the People of Maine and my focus has been solely on the Maine people.   Maine is in a unique position in this debate. Many people may not know that Maine, and specifically our own bipartisan health reforms at the State Legislature, have become the core model of this new health care legislation, which includes some of Maine's models for welfare reforms as well.   With bipartisan Maine reforms at the center of this new bill, and with Maine having ensured essential health benefits and pre-existing conditions are covered under state laws, I have decided to vote yes on this health care legislation.   Under Maine's 2011 bipartisan reforms, those with pre-existing conditions were covered at the same cost as everyone else, with guaranteed coverage. Maine also ensures EHB’s, essential benefits, are always in place through a series of laws confirmed by Maine's Superintendent of Insurance. I am confident that even if Maine State Government sought a waiver not only would Maine people have essential benefits but pre-existing conditions would fully covered. Our state has already proven it—and our state has proven it can dramatically lower some health insurance premiums and stem the tide of rising costs with its reforms. It has worked in Maine.   I expect the U.S. Senate to make further changes to this bill as it moves on from the House and I welcome those changes. I hope it comes back stronger and better. This simply moves this issue on to the Senate.   ObamaCare is failing, and Congress must act to rescue American families.   We were told, under ObamaCare, if we like our health insurance plan and doctor, we could keep them. We were also told the cost of insurance would drop by about $2,500 per year. Tens of thousands of Mainers switched from their plan at work or were forced to get ObamaCare policies.   However, the monthly premiums and annual deductibles for these ObamaCare policyholders have skyrocketed. And, premiums—right here in Maine—are going up another 14-26% this year. Families are paying a fortune and sometimes never even using their ObamaCare coverage, because deductibles are so high. Instead, they oftentimes choose to pay a fine to the IRS rather than accept an ObamaCare plan.   There are only three insurance providers which offer ObamaCare policies in Maine. One of them, Community Health Options in Lewiston lost $58 million last year. Two weeks ago, Anthem announced it would stop offering Maine ObamaCare policies in January if the failing law isn’t changed.   ObamaCare is failing. We must work to fix this dire situation.   There are powerful special interest groups in Augusta and Washington trying to scare us into doing nothing. They say if we change the imploding ObamaCare law, millions of Americans will lose their health insurance.   Families are already losing coverage because their plans have been cancelled by insurance providers.  The special interests say those approaching retirement and the poor won’t be able to afford health insurance if ObamaCare is changed. That’s not true. They can’t afford it now due to high deductibles and increasing premiums.   If the few providers in Maine offering ObamaCare go under or pull out due to continued massive financial losses, we will have no ObamaCare policies in Maine at all. That is not acceptable.   I was elected to Congress to fix our serious problems. That’s exactly what I’m doing.  If we don’t fix this ObamaCare problem, it’s going to get worse.   In Congress, I will continue to push hard to find important solutions to the dire health care problems and challenges for Mainers. ObamaCare is failing and Congress must act to fix it.

Strengthening our national security, and more specifically our nation’s borders, should be of high importance to our government, and I am glad to have acted today to make sure our customs officers and border agents have the tools they need to recruit and hire the very best talent available, while maintaining stringent vetting procedures.

I am taking action so Maine businesses can grow jobs, community banks and credit unions can provide support, and our Maine families can prosper.

ICYMI: Protecting the environment and hundreds of jobs in Washington County.   I am continuing to push for a solution for the dam on the St. Croix River, which could be removed due to new harmful federal regulations. I’m asking the federal government to remove their new regulations on the dam’s management, to protect the environment, the local ecosystem and wildlife, the local community and residents, tourism, sport fishermen, outdoor guides, lodge and property owners, and potentially hundreds of jobs in Washington County. If the dam is removed, it could drastically alter the water levels of the St. Croix and East Grand Lake that could pose disastrously negative consequences for the region and jobs there. I’m pushing hard for a solution.

I was thrilled to join Retired US Army Staff Sgt. Travis Mills this weekend at the grand opening of the Travis Mills Foundation in Rome. The lodge serves as a haven for combat-injured Veterans and their families, who are able to learn reintegration techniques, and enjoy adaptive sports and family recreation at no charge.  I admire Travis’ noble work to help our combat-injured Veterans, having served himself. This year, I introduced legislation to give young Mainers the opportunities to pursue career paths in logging, while also helping to maintain jobs in the industry.  Major advances have been made in Maine’s logging industry in recent years that have drastically improved worker safety. Unfortunately, outdated regulations from Washington haven’t kept up, preventing young Mainers from pursuing careers in the trade in Maine, which largely consists of family-run businesses that have operated for generations in our State.  Yesterday, I’m pleased my bill was included in a larger, bipartisan forestry bill that passed out of committee and moved forward in the House, to help give younger Mainers the tools to success and help the industry thrive in Maine for many more generations to come.

As a proud Franco-American, I believe legal immigration is good for America, as we are truly a Nation of immigrants. However, America is also a Nation of laws, which exist to protect our local towns and communities. When these laws are ignored, it endangers our families and communities and puts our men and women in law enforcement at risk.  Today, the House passed two important measures with bipartisan support to end federal funding to sanctuary cities and implement stronger penalties for those who break our Nation’s immigration laws. Our laws must be enforced and those who break them must be held to account.

650 jobs in Maine make up the sea urchin and sea cucumber harvesting industry. Duplicative regulations from Washington are threatening these Maine jobs, as they’ve forced repetitive, mandatory inspections that have caused the product to be held for prolonged periods and to spoil.  That’s why I’m continuing to work with Democrats and Republicans to solve this problem. I’m asking U.S. Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to review and consider removing these regulations, to help protect our Maine fishing jobs and businesses.

Today in Bangor I introduced my ‘Guaranteed COLA Act,’ a bill to ensure our Seniors and Veterans receive the Social Security benefits they have worked for, earned and deserve. My bill ensures Seniors and Veterans receive a “cost-of-living adjustment,” or COLA, increase to their Social Security of at least 1.5% in 2018, while also eliminating wasteful spending for unused government buildings.

America is a country of immigrants, like my own family. However, no President can simply side-step Congress and create immigration laws on his or her own. The Constitution is clear that the Legislative branch is responsible for passing laws to be presented to the President for signature.  The Obama Administration acted illegally in creating the DACA program in 2012 and, now, the current Administration is facing legal challenges from several states if the DACA policy continues. However, a child should not be held responsible for the actions of parents who chose to break our immigration laws. I believe if those who have been caught in the DACA program have been fully law-abiding members of our society, they should be protected from deportation through legislative action by Congress.  At the same time, we need to continue to secure and control our borders. We need to continue our work to end illegal immigration. Congress must act to improve our border security; to find a solution to address those well-meaning individuals now caught in DACA status; and to update our immigration policies which reduce incentives to break the law. America can continue to be a nation of laws, border security, and controlled immigration.

This new law will drastically simplify our tax code for the vast majority of Mainers and save more money for more of our hardworking families.  Under this simpler tax code, we are doubling the standard deduction, meaning the average married couple in Maine will not pay any federal income tax for the first $24,000 they earn, a huge boost for our families. In addition, this increases the child tax credit to $2,000, meaning the average Maine family will save an additional $2,000 on their taxes per child in their family. This makes it easier for ordinary Maine families to benefit from the tax code.  This improved tax code will also greatly benefit the more than 140,000 small businesses and job creators throughout Maine and their 275,000 employees by lowering the effective rate for pass-throughs, of which almost all small businesses are organized. It will allow small businesses in all industries to benefit from it. We are giving our small businesses—the backbone of Maine’s economy—relief so they can grow and create more jobs for our fellow Mainers.
